Definition: In this task, you get a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is dismissed as anything that is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable that would make someone leave a conversation.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative.

 John Stuart Mill

Comment: Can’t  speak to how easy it is to get a job while homeless, I never had to do it. I’ll wager that in this day and age, the market for strong, unskilled backs isn’t what it used to be. If someone has a need for such labor, they could surely save themselves some time and effort by simply passing out flyers where homeless types congregate.

People can have different perceptions of a given situation. I see a lot of poverty out there, more than I see a hostile and dangerous environment. My attitude could change if a homeless guy mugged me I suppose, but then I could be "mugged" by a guy in a mansion just as easily, so... Until then, I’m not going to let fear dictate my actions, I will continue to walk/ride the streets, while avoiding some of them in the late evening.

I don’t know what convening yet another panel is going to accomplish, the issue runs a lot deeper than that. The police are constrained by what the city’s policies are, so I wouldn’t expect miracles from the new chief.

Comment: I want to separate out the nonsense of the Kathy Griffins and Ted Nugents of the world from stuff that really matters. Show business people are, for the most part, self-indulgent children, and the fact that technology gives them all kinds of platforms these days doesn't mean they are worth paying attention to.

But what elected officials say and do does matter. I'm not so naive as to believe there ever was a time in U.S. history when politicians were governed by either civility or honesty, but the wildcard today is the immediate impact their words can have, and rarely for good.

Trump's insomnia-driven tweets aren't harmless. One stupid comment from him at 4 a.m. can dominate the news cycle for the next 24 hours, putting Democrats into response mode and Republicans into damage control mode. And while all that's happening, the work of the country isn't getting done.

This president's lack of personal discipline exhausts Congress, the media and the nation. And that's not a good thing.

Comment: If we read the story of Adam and Eve without prejudice, at face value, it raises many more troubling questions about the nature of God than about the nature of woman.  Why did God choose to create human beings with such capacity for curiosity and temptation?  Why did God place the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil in the garden?  Why did God allow the serpent in the garden?  Certainly Adam and Eve did not will the serpent to be there (or whatever realities all these symbols intend to portray).  And if Eve lived in a sinless paradise, she was naive of any knowledge of deceit or cunning, and she appears to be more curious than rebellious.  There is also no evidence that she seduced or tricked Adam, he appears to have been there the whole time.  The story to me shows that God is much more unpredictable, welcoming of risk, and, dare I say, mischievous, than we would like to believe.  Poor Eve has become the object of all our disavowed discomfort and uncertainty about the nature of God

Comment: Each state has its own rules for car insurance too, but we are able to buy auto insurance across state lines at a substantially reduced rate from what we could do when states only allowed 1 or 2 companies to cover there.

If you were a government worker, you could get GEICO, but nobody else could. I paid about $25 less per month then with All State as I pay now. Yes, I was in my 20s, but my brother was older and he reports a similar experience.

To say it can't be done and then refuse to try it is to buy into their statist bull. We  don't know that it won't work until we've tried it.

And, by the way, in the 1980s, the eilite status quo junkies said opening auto insurance across statelines wouldn't work because laws in each state were so different; it would be chaos. But we tried it and it worked.

We need to be patient with the various US Law Enforcement Agencies and Congress while they conduct their investigations.

If it is determined that a Head of State or persons acting at the behest of a Head of State, as it was with Watergate, were involved with the 2016 attempt, then our nation must act with the same determination and resolve to bring that Head of State down and to bring all persons involved to justice, as we did in 1972.

The nationality of the persons who may have committed such acts are not important; their behavior and our determination to prevent further occurrences is all that matters.

Lets be patient and support the process.

Comment: I have some replies for PI:

1.  I remember in 2008 to 2010 that all over the country emergency rooms were closing in small, rural hospitals. The reason was exactly as you said -- the emergency rooms were obliged to accept patients without insurance. There were so many people without insurance in those communities that hospitals were going broke. This was also exacerbated by the trend of turning hospitals into for-profit businesses.

3 and 4.  So many of our notions of tax incentives and employer-sponsored health care don't apply to the people who really need help. My friend works at Sam's Club -- he has no health insurance and no benefits. He is not allowed to work enough hours to qualify -- they keep him 15 minutes short every week. He makes barely enough money to survive and pays no taxes. How will tax incentives help him? He is just hanging on until he qualifies for Medicare.

On the other hand, your attempt to attribute the clerical sex abuse scandal to the phenomenon of gay priests is spurious, IMHO. The fact that most of the victims are male, which appears to be your essential evidence, is just not relevant. Frequently sex abusers, straight or gay, are essentially sexually underdeveloped, sexually immature, even to the point if some cases of not having yet figured out with clarity their own sexual orientation. Comment: This is a good example of what the information revolution is supposed to be achieving, but it comes with the same perils that the article is talking about. I mean, we all research health information on the internet, and hopefully we are good at picking out reliable sources, but it's also true that there is a huge amount of misinformation available.

For instance, the anti-vaccination movement has been very active on the internet, and that is definitely a negative for public health.

More generally, it can be very hard to sort out genuine experts from dilettantes. This is ultimately why we still need governments and health authorities, and why it is so important to approach the internet with cautious skepticism even as we gain a lot of value from the information it makes available.

Comment: "an 8 percent reduction would mean 2.16 million pounds less fish, representing a $6.83 million loss to the industry." 

"They paid $200,000 last year for 1,000 tons to the Marianas.

2.16 Million pounds       =           980 Tons      =         $6.82 Million 

Paid to the Marianas    =         1,000 Tons      =         $0.20 Million   ($200K)

Of course the argument will be that the former is a "gross" figure, and the latter is a "net" figure. True.

Assuming a reasonable "net profit" in the circa 10% range, the truer Longline Industry "loss" is closer to $682,000. 

Even on this basis, the Marianas get shafted. 

By raising fishermens' salaries 8%, with a pass-through of 4% increase to the market, any loss in wages 
could be offset. 

I think we'd gladly pay an extra 4% for our fish to see this monument happen. 

TP Gallagher

P.s. If the long-liners sold directly at Tsukiji, cutting out brokers, the premium would easily offset this "loss."

Comment: Use the WSP Collision Analysis Tool found at:
https://fortress.wa.gov/wsp/collisionanalysistool/Query/SearchCriteria
Takes a few tries to know what you don't need to put in the fields (keep it to a minimum).
Don't try to do all within the tool, export "big" data to Excel. You find all sorts of things when looking at data without an "app" finding specifics.
I requested all fatalities in WA state, and see the name "US 2" is reported in many formats, so manual review once data is exported is needed. This is common in databases, especially for something where the team building the database won't have a clue what roads are called in WA state, both officially, and what WSP knows them by.
Only armchair quarterbacks would know these things.
Always look at the root data. Those who don't are easy to spot by those who do.
Now, as fun as it is to know the ACTUAL situation, it's all moot.
As you know, if it saves one life, then it's worth someone else spending every cent you and I have.

Comment: Pinocchio raises a good point but...HAPA is a 501c3, limited to the amount of lobbying it may conduct and may not support individual candidates in an election.  HAPA conducts the nonpartisan Kuleana Academy that trains emerging political leaders how to run for public office, but HAPA does not support individual candidates running for office.  The academy features speakers from all political parties (Democratic, Republican and Green).  Some Kuleana Academy graduates from the original 2016 class did get creamed and others came very close to winning.  The Spring 2017 Kuleana Class recently concluded and a third program will start in Sept.. As to who will lead the political/electoral revolution?  That will not be HAPA as its legal structure limits the activities it may engage in.  However, I am confident that the emerging network of people and organizations who are so, so tired of business as usual in Hawaii politics will collectively manage the revolution just fine.

Comment: There was not any printing press in the Second Century.  The Liturgy was adopted to the area [province] where the people WERE Christian and celebrated.  There certainly wasn't any Liturgical 'watch-dog' group over-seeing developments in the liturgy.  This was done, not only in Greek, but in other languages in which the Liturgy was celebrated.  At this time, there was no Eastern and Western Churches.  For example, in the Chaldean and  Assyrian Rites, there are no words of Institution of the Eucharist, no consecration.  This went on for centuries [yes, they were and are faithful Catholics].  It was acknowledged with an agreement only on October 26, 2001.  There were other places during the Liturgies, where there is reference to the words of Jesus.

When the Benedictine Order was established, the monks undertook the task of printing by hand---Sacred Scripture and the Liturgy.  But there were mistakes as well in the hand printing.  When humans do anything, there are errors.

Comment: I tried it for a few minutes but quickly lost patience. Mostly what I learned from the biofeedback experience was to slow down my breathing. I use that sometimes to try to get to sleep and sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. I think some of us are born with highly reactive nervous systems, which are also not well-suited to meditation practices, including progressive relaxation. Our minds and bodies don't "sit still" that long. 

I liked the biofeedback approach because it was mechanical: all I had to do was breathe and look at the moving chart on the computer screen. In did produce results for quite a while and I think in time would have trained me to do it without the computer. Wasn't able to do it long enough.

I would like to find a way to do that on my home computer. So far I haven't found an affordable way to get the necessary sensors and software. Amazon sells some simple biofeedback gadgets but customer comments do not inspire confidence.

Comment: The Oregon State Bar's handling of ethics complaints against members is a sham. 

I filed a complaint against a local attorney, working for developers' interests, who wrote an e-mail to the Eugene Deputy City Attorney encouraging her to “share word of Mr. Conte's attempted extortion with others in the city.”

This was a clear violation of ethics rule 4.4 (a) "In representing a client or the lawyer’s own interests, a lawyer shall not use means that have no substantial purpose other than to embarrass, delay, harass or burden a third person ***.

Despite having a copy of the e-mail, Helen Hierschbiel, the OSB General Counsel, dismissed the complaint.

My rejoinder summarized: 

_"If the position description for OSB General Council requires shielding members of the bar from accountability, you would appear well-qualified. If the position is supposed to maintain public confidence in the integrity of the Oregon Bar, you appear to to be a poor choice."_

-- Paul

Comment: I have been retired for four years. I did as you say. I started with historical spending patterns as a base for my retirement spending projections. Then made assumptions about investment returns, inflation and taxes. I am an accountant, so the complex calculations were manageable. If you are not an accountant and not adept with spreadsheets, I would recommend hiring and independent financial advisor. I hired one, just to double check my work. It a takes about an hour a month to update my expenses and redo my projections. This must be done every month. I manage my own investments too. As they are primarily equity investments, monitoring them takes about an hour a day. If you have someone else monitor your investments and or invest in broad based passively managed, index mutual funds or ETF's then less time monitoring your investments will be required. Good luck.

Comment: If your parents talked with you about their field of expertise, then, as the child of linguists, it would seem that you would appreciate the fact that language does not stop developing, as long as there are people who speak the given language. 
For the past 40 years, it the US, there has been much conversation about inclusive language, and inclusive language is now considered the norm by many in the US.   (And, by the way, the term refers to an actual phenomenon, so there is no need to put it in quotes.)   To say that "Jesus died for all men" is simply inaccurate; our belief is that Jesus died for all people.  
I fail to understand the opposition among some to the evolution of American English.  In the US, it is becoming (and in certain cases has become) generally accepted that "man" refers to male humans, and that "people", or "humanity", or "human beings", or "men and women" are terms that refer to both male and female human beings.

Comment: The data is drawn from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health and, as the study authors note, involves weighting to balance for region and demographic characteristics. 

The Experiences of Discrimination (EOD) scale is a multi-item set of measures. Very well validated and the gold standard. Complex measures to reflect what is a complex experience. The authors are suggesting the single item approach of the AAH study they draw from might not be accurately capturing discriminatory experience due to the simplicity of the question. 

The question was included in what was a study of health in order to generate data to explore the relationship between discrimination and racism and health experiences and outcomes. Because the AAH questionnaire is so large, I presume they did not want to use the EOD because it would add to survey length.

But the caveat is a huge one that comes very close to invalidating the data on discrimination.

Comment: As someone with zero use for Donald Trump I have been openly condemning any and all violence that is initiated by those in opposition to the president. In some situations, notably the recent skirmish in Berkeley, Antifa has been the cause of the troubles. It would not have turned violent without them.

That said, I will not be drawn into the game of false moral equivalence. Those who march under the Nazi or Confederate flags have embraced ideologies that specifically call for the degradation of human life, and even the deaths of humans (there were white supremacists in Charlottesville calling for the death of Jews among other things). It's not a matter of good people on both sides. There are no good Nazis.

There are plenty on the right who have recognized this, including both of Alaska's senators. They responded with honor. While I don't side with the left (I identify as centrist), when I see good people on both sides condemning the bad people on their own side, I see cause for hope.

Funding essential government functions is not at issue.

Anchorage School District, public-employee unions, clients of city lobbyists, large campaign donors, non-profit organizations which make no payments in lieu of taxes, vocal minority of park enthusiasts, advocates of mail-in voting for starters...

Comment: Re: Charleston shooter's "criminal record"

No, the 72-hour limit had nothing to do with his getting a gun.

Federal law (18 USC 922(g) and (d)) applies to those convicted of, or under indictment for, a crime punishable by more than one year in prison. The Charleston shooter was charged with (not yet convicted of) the crime of possession of a controlled substance. Under South Carolina law, that's a misdemeanor. The case documents refer to "charge code 0179" - maximum of 6 months in jail.

The only question is whether a single charge (without conviction) means he's an "unlawful user of, or addicted to, a controlled substance". The federal definition of that term (27 CFR 478.11) says an inference may be drawn from multiple arrests, a conviction, or a drug test - it doesn't say anything about a single charge without a conviction. Perhaps an admission of possession would be enough? (Arrest report alleges he admitted possession of suboxone without a prescription.)

I know this observation will set off the usual howls about Toronto having an absurdly puffed-up view of itself and thinking itself to be "the centre of the universe" but it's true. Global surveys by companies like Mercer and The Economist rank Toronto as one of the world's best cities to live in. By global standards Toronto real estate is still pretty cheap.

Comment: The State income tax deduction is a de facto Federal subsidy to high tax states.  If your state has a sales tax,  and no income tax,  you get zero benefit for subsidizing CA and NY.  Or Oregon.  

The under represented tax by the Feds is SSI.  It applies to first $127,200 in wages.  7.65% by employer and 7.65% by employee.  After that limit,  there is only Medicare tax to pay which is 1.45% by employer and 1.45% by employee.  $200,000 and over of salary and wages,  and the Medicare by employer stays the same and employee is raised to 2.35%.   All of which says the big public employee earners are getting a pay raise when their overtime and/or salaries exceed $127,200.  Their taxes  go down by 6.2%.  Yet the poorest who earn an hour of minimum wage have to pay the SSI and Medicare taxes on their first dollar and all after to $127K.   Zero forgiveness. That is regressive.  Even though they will most likely collect more than they pay by a huge margin,  if they live long enough to collect

Comment: Feb 29th 1504 was a good day for Christopher Columbus too. For several months the famous explorer had been marooned on the island of Jamaica. He had been greeted warmly by the natives who helped him and his vast ship and crew survive in the foreign land by providing food and guides etc. However his arrogance and disrespect for the people had caused them to stop this gesture of goodwill. Cause, you know, he was being a dick.

Outraged by this, Columbus consulted his shipboard almanac to ask if there was anything he could use to trick the natives. As it happens, there was a lunar eclipse coming up. On the 29th feb, the day of the eclipse, he gathered the natives and told them that god was angry for their disrespect and would take away the sun. Disappearing inside his ship during the eclipse, he waited as the good people begged for their women and children. He agreed to 'bring the sun back', and essentially enslaved the people until he was rescued.

WHAT A DICK.

Comment: I would recommend they hire someone to research officers' everyday work and develop a fitness test that reflects what would generally be required in the course of their duty.

The main issue with generalized "fitness" tests is they'll use place-holder activities to try to gauge ability without recognizing that performance on those tasks may be influenced by factors other than what they're claiming to measure. Ex: arm/ab strength being equal, push-ups will be harder for females due to the different center of gravity/weight distribution. For similar reasons, it's easier to hip-throw/trip/unbalance a male if you're doing grappling/take-down exercises. A test where people have to carry a heavy pack puts females at a disadvantage, even with strength and endurance being equal, if the packs were designed with a male form in mind and the weight distribution and shape of the pack was not adjusted as needed. Etc. Ideally, you would have sets of tasks people could select from to show aptitude.

Comment: I meant half of the region (~50%), not half of 60%.

I recall the surveys that had a very high % of respondents said something needed to be done about foreign $. I want you to be right that a vast majority would actually support something significant being done. 

The question that needs to be asked of owners is: how would you feel about the value of your property falling by 30-50%? Because that's the end result that starts to make the region more viable long-term, regardless of the drivers of high prices.

I have seen a lot of sympathetic and thoughtful head nodding about foreign $ and people willing to acknowledge that it's far harder to get into the market than it was in the past. But if you suggest that prices should even fall back to 2015 levels (~30% decrease), many people are less enthused (even though that would be the natural outcome of meaningfully addressing foreign $ or local debt gorging). YMMV. But that's been my experience and the experience of friends.

Comment: This story  and its experts do not address the event well.

This was the first instance of trading strategy designed to reduce risk changed the distributions in which it expected to traffic.

Portfolio insurance is a model that buys stock index futures when the index rises and sells when it drops.  In 1987 the model was completely mechanical and kept selling through the day.  At one point the futures were down almost 15% more than the stocks as a bunch did not open.

Interestingly portfolio insurance gave was to TAA in the 1990 that muted market volatility for a decade until it fell out of favour.

Likewise. 1998 was a similar event where quantitative risk management and arbitrage trading induced similar results in spread trades, ultimately taking out LTCM at its epicenter. 

Even 20078 can be presented as a risk model based crisis.

Understanding market structure is a key to successful investing, but it is a topic poorly understood.  The best academic work is by Richard Bookstaber.

Comment: The difference will be how the money is spent, what the soldiers are allowed to do and what they actually do. In 2012 at Bagram I saw the 10th Sustainment Brigade out of Ft Drum. Mechanics, electricians, truck drivers, all the support people that line units lack in any great numbers. Great idea to send them. Except, on Bagram Macedonians and Bosniaks with a few Afghans did the work the soldiers could have done. What did happen was that about 1 out of every 60 went downrange to work on Combat Outposts(COP). The rest stayed on Bagram, worked out at the gym, went shopping and hit salsa night at the MWR. Reality was that only about 2 companies of the brigade needed to be there. But colonels don't get promoted for staying at home, so everybody went. There's a few thousand of the troops right there. Our effort has been similar in nature in every aspect. Money, material, people, all mismanaged from the top.

Comment: I cannot comment on the state of the medical system in Ontario although 3 years without a contract does seem like a rather long time. What I can comment on from experience is binding arbitration. Of course they would like it - everybody does. But what happens with binding arbitration. It is the step ladder effect. The group looks around and demands slightly more than their neighbour or the highest paid similar group at the time. It ensures ongoing increases in compensation independent of merit (i.e. police, fire fighters, etc). So I would strongly suggest the Province NOT agree to binding arbitration as a way of resuming talks.

Comment: It took Hurricane Hazel to shock people in Southern Ontario into the insight that building your home on a flood plain was not a good decision. And so conservation authorities were organized around the river systems so that when (not if) the next "storm of the century" came the damage could be limited. The problem, as I see it, is that the protective measures anticipated a certain level of urban growth, not the explosive expansion of suburbs onto what was once the prime agricultural land of southern Ontario. All those suburbs have roads and roofs which collect the downpour and deliver it directly into the headwaters of the river systems, resulting in greater than anticipated flow further downstream. Consider the new suburbs south of Caledon Mountain - and the glut of water they add to the original streams after a deluge.  The sensible solution would be to stop the expansion of suburbs onto farmland - but good luck getting that past the politicians and the developer lobby.

Comment: The intent of the tax incentives for Boeing was for the company to build the aircraft in Washington State with what that implies, however, if the state intended to tie employment figures to it, that's what should have been included in the agreement IF Boeing would agree to it. Whether Boeing would agree to that of not is speculation at this point, but the fact is employment was numbers were NOT a condition of for the tax incentives granted to Boeing. For the state to try to add employment numbers to the current agreement is unethical and cannot be permitted without BOTH parties, the Washington State and the Boeing Company, agreeing to renegotiate. If the state reneges or attempts to impose additional conditions, then the entire agreement cannot be enforced and Boeing could just pack up, lock, stock and barrel and move to Charleston or anywhere else that would provide a more business friendly climate, to the total detriment of Washington.

Comment: tompaine:  I think your response illustrates just how complex and contentious the homeless issue is.  To be sure, I agree that many (not all) homeless individuals would be less than enjoyable everyday companions....meth addicts, chronic alcoholics, the mentally ill, and others need extensive, and expensive, treatment; not mere companionship.  The question of "mandated" treatment is a contentious, but important, topic.  There are no "easy"answers and, with so many different presenting issues, each homeless individual needs an individualized plan if meaningful assistance is to be provided.  Such intervention is both expensive and intrusive.  Many persons don't want to spend the money and many others don't want to intrude into people's lives.  I'd suggest effective intervention would likely be both expensive and intrusive........so here we are.  regards, Gary

Comment: These people are a software company. Developers need quiet time to do their best work. No distractions. No conversations within earshot. Of course there needs to be collaboration. Sometimes it's in meetings, sometimes it's in the kitchen, and sometimes it's in the hallways. But it's never at the desk, unless you have a private office and can close the door.

Different groups within a company have different needs. The needs of sales and marketing are radically different from HR, administration, and in this case, software development. To try and claim that each are the same is beyond ridiculous.

Then there is management. How do you discuss performance if not in private? What if a customer calls you and has a complaint about one of your employees? How do you begin to discuss the issue when they are sitting right there, next to you?!

And don't get me started about "flat" organizations!

But I am sure that you made this work for you in your situation. Congratulations!

Comment: As a manager in a workplace where working from home has not been part of the culture, but the work itself can be done remotely (and HR has a neutral stance, leaving it to managers/units to decide), the main problem my colleagues and I face is that granting this request for one employee means granting it for others who may be more junior (i.e. We have not been able to fully assess their effectiveness/abilities/strengths and otherwise yet), or who we are less confident would work well at home. We are now testing out a program where folks with good performance reviews who have worked with us for more than 1 year can request a 3-month trial period working from home starting 1-day per week and working up to 50% of the time from home after 6 months if all goes well. We will revisit the whole program after 18 months. So far so good!!

Good luck!

Comment: Bill:  IMO, the first step to improvement in anything is to identify the problems which need to be addressed....to identify the "shortcomings", then to plan and take actions toward improvement.  "looking at the negative" does not, IMO, lead to depression...."dwelling on the negative" does.  If my car won't start I can whine about it, I can say "or well" and start walking, or I can say "geez, I'd better fix it" and do so.  The first, indeed, leads to depression; the second ignores the problem and the third is a positive quest for a solution.  I'll take the third option every time.  regards, Gary Crum

Comment: Mr. Moreno:  I think you make a good point.  It would be nice if there was no "hate" speech or even "offensive" speech on campus, or, in fact, anywhere.  As you say, that's not the way things are.  We all, including students, are ocassionally subjected to remarks we find offensive, hurtful or inciteful.  We may become offended, have our feeling hurt or become angry.....perhaps some combination of the three.  

It's difficult and IMO, often iappropriate to attempt to control the free speech of others.  Where's the line between "hate speech" and "offensive speech" and, on the offensive side of that very gray line, is it really our place to silence the comments of others?  How should we react to such comments?  Should we endure them and "ignore" them?  Should we respond "in kind"? Should we attempt to address them in some non-violent confrontative fashion?  Or should we look to some outside agency to take care of us and deal with what we see as a problem?  No easy answers  regards, Gary

Comment: North Korea has had the ability to strike Alaska with a missile since at least 2006.  The 2006 missile launch by North Korea came within 250 miles of northern California.  In 2009 North Korea launched a rocket capable of taking a 220 pound satellite 250 miles into orbit, or delivering a 2,200 pound warhead 3,700 miles - which puts Alaska well within range.

Having a rocket with an effective range is one thing, putting a small enough nuclear warhead on that missile and guiding it to a desired location is another thing entirely.  North Korea is no serious threat.  The biggest problem with North Korea is that they act as middle-men for Russian-made missiles and weapons to countries and organizations that wouldn't have access otherwise.  For example, North Korea supplied Iraq with Scuds during the 1991 Gulf War, and has been supplying Iran both missile and nuclear technology (along with Pakistan) since the late-1990s.

Comment: Any attempt to change the time to DST all year would be a disaster. The government in Edmonton, of all places, should know this. A sunrise time of 9:15am in the height of winter would easily be enough to put our kids to sleep in 1st period, it is proven fact. People in general would be more tired, more likely to cause accidents when they are still drowsy in the morning. If they are interested on keeping the time the same throughout the year then the only responsible solution is to keep standard time all year round.

Portugal did the same thing in the nineties and it failed miserably, they had to switch back. It caused more trouble than it was worth. Northwest Spain is currently in the same scenario and is suffering as a result. Albertans must not adopt all year DST.

Comment: I'm a cab driver and a plate owner. The author did his homework, but he is telling one side of the story to make it juicy.

Plates no longer cost $360,000 but instead they go for about $100,000. Also, income earn from a taxi drivers has been halved, since Uber has taken most of the business. Given these figures, the traditional taxi industry should be extinct.  Just look at the numbers, If a driver was clearing about $120 in a bad day, he's now clearing $60 because Uber has taken over 1/2 pie.  

I'm sure Uber is smarting over the fact that the taxi industry has not collapsed since they're hemorrhaging billions to take it over.  Reason being, is because these supposed despot taxi plate holder have waved all but a token amount of the fees they're been collecting for their taxi plates. And in some case, they've been digging into their own pockets to keep the car on the road.  Consequence is that it's now cheaper to drive a taxi cab owned by someone else vs putting your own on the road.

Comment: My journalism training, like Dermot's, was in the Watergate era, which launched a golden age of American journalism.  Media were still just print, network TV and radio, so space was a limited resource, which in turn made economic competition viable.  It also limited voices, and while that sounds negative, it had the effect of keeping public debate, and public tastes, somewhat more focused.  Compare to the current regime, in which media can't survive economically without control of a whole market, while individual voices explode all over the internet--which, in turn, has become most people's primary source of information.  This harms institutional media economically, but it also scatters public debate and tastes so widely that there is no overarching set of principles that governs either.  Classically, this is described as decadence.

Thank you, Dermot, for reminding me, here and in all your writing, of that golden age.

Comment: I don't dispute that there are objective standards. I just think it's important to admit that they are human standards, not divine. And I also don't dispute that everything we do in liturgy should be done well and with intentionality. God certainly deserves our "first fruits."

I only take issue with the presumption that some musical styles are more intrinsically pleasing to God when, to the best of my knowledge, God has never revealed that information.

Conversations like this bring to mind the old saying about funerals being for the living. I think the same principle can be applied to liturgy. We come together to worship God, but the styles and forms involved in how we do it are really about human tastes. God's glory isn't diminished by poor liturgy any more than it's enhanced by great liturgy. The loss or gain is all on our part.

Comment: I'm a testing Coordinator at a public Middle School in the metro area and I'm going to tell you a secret. Students aren't tested heavily in Colorado.

The PARCC exams are state mandated for grades 3-10 and require three sixty minute sessions each. They are over a month long testing window. Most schools spread them over a week. The only other state mandated exam are for students designated as English Language Learners (They take an six part that takes about two hours total). Students in 11th grade also take the SAT. 

That means that most students are only in mandated testing six hours a YEAR. 

Any other acronym exam they take, STAR (for math) or SRI (for reading), are 15 minute, non-mandated, placement tests that help teachers drive instruction and aren't something kids can "opt-out" of just like a kid can't opt out of his US History midterm. 

But hey, the same people complaining about testing want high stakes accountability for kids... you can't have your cake and eat it too.

I think you will find the concerns about safety are quite legitimate.  As I understand it (after talking with hazmat experts) the crude oil being shipped by rail is actually far more dangerous than refined product like gasoline or diesel.  Hundreds or thousands of Eugene residents would be affected (hurt, killed, evacuated) by a leak and fire like the one that just happened in Mosier last year.  The local government has very little ability to hold the railroad accountable for rail safety and maintenance in town.  While I agree with the authors at the RG, that a national plan would be ideal, I won't hold my breath for federal action on this front...at least not at this point.

Comment: Public schools are a bit like the post office. People point to FedEx for example and say, "look how a private company can do it better!" In the case of mail, FedEx can take on the most profitable aspects of package delivery and do that well, while the Post Office has to deliver postcards to some ranch in Wyoming (at a loss). Schools are like that also. Public schools must educate all children, which means if a kid comes in with severe behavioral issues then they need to hire someone to watch over them. Private schools don't have this kind of overhead, so can run leaner. Reaching that last house (for mail), or last child (for schools) is disproportionately expensive.

Comment: IRT "State ID"  If the State would go out to the community, there would be hundreds less residents going to DMVs to get a State ID.  In 2010, we had 4 members of our family go to Mililani High School cafeteria on a Saturday when the State came out to issue IDs.  There were several hundred people getting IDs.  This would significantly bring down the number of people going to DMVs.  Process was a lot faster than going to a DMV.  The 4 of us were done in less than an hour. Go out to a different community every 6 months and cut the lines at DMVs.

This is the first step in treatment of glioblastoma, followed by radiation and chemotherapy. McCain was not "sewn up and sent home", his glioblastoma was excised, the cranial plug replaced, and the incision sewed up. This is all in the NYTimes as of this week. If you think the brain surgeon didn't suspect the most common and aggressive cancer, I think you have misled yourself. A subdural hematoma alone typically is caused by a blow to the head.

Comment: Again, your initial disclaimer for your commentary is justified.

Note that I clearly stated that CO₂ is "the single most significant GHG in terms of INITIATING global temperature change". The water vapor mixing ratio only changes with temperature, and is a feedback to CO₂ changes. And again, the consensus estimate for the contribution to the GHE from water vapor is ~50% (not 91%), and the contribution from CO₂ is ~20%. 20% of 33K is not "3 C".

Water vapor is indeed the closest thing to a "black body" selective absorber, but it does so quite near the surface. The energy balance is determined by the energy flux differential at the effective emission height significantly higher in the troposphere where water vapor is scarce, and CO₂ remains well-mixed. In contrast to your odd assertion of "not much energy" at the absorption band of CO₂, a quick look at the Earth's Planck curve with GHG interaction tells a different story.

https://chriscolose.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/rad4.gif

Comment: Good post.  Can't fathom a "noted Indigenous" person actually believing this.  

I've done a far amount of reading about the fur trade (Eastern Canada/US; west coast, Fort Vancouver to Fort George) and the trade in what is now Alberta, too.  I'd sure like evidence of how FN people "dominated the relationship."  If they entered into a relationship with Northwest Company, HBC or American independents, there was only ONE dominant partner: the one who used/controlled the liquor (which was introduced at the beginning, back in the 1600s.)

In Canada, I know of only one FN people who "controlled" the situation: B.C.'s Tsilhqot'in people. In the 1820s, they agreed to trade,  but decided they needed their furs to keep warm in the winter, so never traded them!  Worse, they actually AVOIDED two recently-established HBC posts in their territory (on the west side of the Fraser River) and just...never came in.  

Result: HBC man Donald McLean was forced to close up the posts!

Comment: Often that type of tagging can be cleaned off if a few things go right - the sooner the better as the paints haven't yet completely volatized the solvents and are still soft. This is the point a mild solvent such as turpentine, paint thinner, etc can work.  It helps if the tagging is not facing the sun.  The last thing that helps a bunch is what paint was originally used for, in this case, painting the train. A good epoxy or such will stand up to solvents.  Looks like in this case all the elements were there!  Good on those that cleaned it up, that was one massive job even with the lucky breaks.  Bravo!

Comment: Notice the author writes of "journalism," rather than "news." This is key to understanding his motivation (and by association, that of Civil Beat). The author appears to be attempting to justify pandering to reader demographic's needs, wants, and desires. Given his background, this is not surprising.

But this view completely ignores that news -- which Civil Beat purports to be providing -- is an entirely different beast. News is reflective of reality, regardless of how or whether the reader wants to hear it. It creates the accurate situational awareness citizens in a democracy need in order to make appropriate decisions at polling time.

Sadly, the journalism espoused in this article merely perpetuates the discredited mainstream media's stranglehold on filtering what gets reported and in what light it is presented. This is not what I was taught long ago in journalist school.

Give the readers unadulterated facts and trust they are smart enough to know what to do with that information.

Comment: 1/ You wrote:

<<An increasing number of historians claim that on average, oral tradition is not more or less reliable than written tradition.>>

Like who? Oral tradition is highly speculative. You might be satisfied by a "credible-enough" standard, but I don't think that's how it works among the pros.

<<falsity requires actual proof to the contrary>>

Really? Zeus impregnated Leda. Please produce actual proof to the contrary.

2. "the epistle of Clement of Alexandria 'To Theodore'"; Please, please tell us all about Clement's letter to Theodore! :)

cont.

Continue to pay out a full pfd, and the majority of Alaskans, will not notice much of a change in income. Couple this with an activation of the tax that kicks in when budget reserves fall below 90 day reserve and stop taxing when reserves go above a 120 day reserve, aka only tax workers when it's absolutely needed and you have a fair and balanced solution. We live in an era in which energy costs will be climbing.  Get over it so we can get on with it.

John Meyer

The ACA is a mess and when it finally does fail, it will do so in dramatic fashion.  How many providers in AK?

§ 1. Public Education

The legislature shall by general law establish and maintain a system of public schools open to all children of the State, and may provide for other public educational institutions. The University of Alaska is hereby established as the state university and constituted a body corporate. It shall have title to all real and personal property now or hereafter set aside for or conveyed to it. Its property shall be administered and disposed of according to law.

Comment: I hope he can beat the cancer and live an even longer life.  

BUT... I think he should resign from the Senate and let the governor appoint a replacement.  He's about to turn 81 years old.  Even if he does beat the cancer and recover from this, it will be a slow, long slog with long stretches away from the Senate.  If he were younger with the prospect of a long career in the Senate afterward, it would be a different matter.  But let's face it -- he's long past that point now.  

He'd just be doing a disservice to the Senate, the country, and his party if he doesn't step down and hand the reigns to someone else.  Especially now, while his party has a slim 52 seat majority where as we've seen, just a few Senators on each end of the spectrum can torpedo legislation.  Even one vote is HUGE.   

We thank you for all your great contributions and sacrifices to the country, Senator.  You're a true American hero.  Please don't put a black mark on the end of that record now.

Comment: First time commenting?  The PDN's been using Civil Comments for quite a while now.

I like it, now that I'm used to it  --  it's the extension of the "community standards" definition of obscenity to define what is civil discourse.  

Most of the comments I'm asked to rate are not even from the PDN, so there's no way I can pursue a vendetta against commenters I don't like.  

If a rater hands out too many "uncivil" ratings, they lose their posting privileges.  

And even if every rater rated a comment as "bad," nothing happens.  

I think it works just fine.

I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: I was actually drafted into the Distributism group by John Medaille and had him on my radio show to discuss it. Comment: Divino Afflante Spiritu (1943) authorized the use of the original texts, which in the case of the Old Testament means chiefly Hebrew.  "Occidere" is a fairly close translation of the Hebrew "ratsach" which means both "kill" and "murder" and derives from a root which means "to cut up." Jerome was not a whiz at Hebrew or Aramaic, but he got it right in his Vulgate with a Latin verb which does some justice to the Hebrew.  The English translation "murder" is narrower than the Hebrew original and the Latin (Vulgate) translation "occidere."

Comment: ArthurC,
 The Pardon and Clemency Board that use exist was comprised of three members, Lt.Governor,Head of Criminal Division department of law, and one public member (Knowles administration had a victim rights activist). People applying for pardons or clemency filled out applications with attachments. The designated staff at Corrections reviewed the applications, added their report with information regarding the applicant's behavior, the crime, investigation,trial and sentencing. Verify applicant's references, medical information if pertinent, add correspondence if any. No applications were screen out. The staff person made their recommendation in writing. Overall it was very detailed and comprehensive.
The three members received by mail every quarter the application packets. They met via teleconference. Each application was discussed, questions made to staff, discussion and vote or tabled until next meeting for information requested. After voting, made recommendations to Governor.

Comment: The regime of mandatory testing of transportation employees arose in the USA during the hey-day of America's War on Drugs. It wasn't an initiative of the transport safety regulators, but of politicians who saw something they could trumpet as action on the country's wider social issue. The bottom line? Have airline accidents due to pilot error (of any cause whatsoever) been reduced since mandatory testing was brought in. No. It remains at the very low level it's been at for decades.

Like all aspects of airline safety, the issue of pilot capacity-to-fly should be examined on a regular basis. And that's exactly what's being done in Canada at this time. Knee-jerk political responses to extremely isolated events is the American approach. We take a more measured approach in Canada, and it's never failed us yet.

Comment: We'll wait for the remaining ballots to see if the Liberal have a majority or minority.  What we do know for certain is that the NDP failed to get the most seats, and failed to top popular vote. They only thing they achieved is to bring uncertainty and chaos into the Legislature. That will ripple through citizens and businesses who hire.

Other than the Green spike, the only thing that happened was that the NDP got the same pop vote they did in the 2013 loss (but less than Gordon Campbells last two victories), and through riding re-distribution, picked up a few more seats. They didn't gain any new voters since Dix. None.

Strategically, the outcome is perfect for the centre-right; the NDP failed to form government, and will sit on the sidelines until next election, shut out for 2 decades, a generation. But, they've given the province enough of a scare that Liberals can play on that leading up to 2021. What we will now see is the Greens being recognized as the 'effective' opposition.

Comment: Dear H2: I applaud your ideas and suggestions of alternative energy for our state because there are a lot of options. But our current situation is that the state has progressed through serious studies and engineering exercises to develop a potential project, the gas line to tidewater with LNG sales to interested parties. The question is whether or not to proceed and spend piles and piles of money to move forward. There is definitely a market for LNG depending on the delivered price. Now our consultants tell us the delivered price for our LNG is not competitive. If we believe them we should scrap the AKLNG project, if we don't believe them why did we hire them in the first place? If AKLNG dies, then we could go back to look at other alternatives and see which merit further cost development. But we have a question before us to be decided, AKLNG or not. We can't start trying to redesign the whole premise, that could look a lot like the ANC port project with massive cost overruns.

Comment: Rmiller101: Of course tearing it up would be devastating. After NAFTA came into effect the trade volume between its 3 signatories increased immensely, and is now around $1 trillion per year.  That is a vast amount of trade on the line here -- not to say that it would all stop without NAFTA, but even a relatively low percentage disruption could mean millions of jobs lost.

I don't think that Trump has actually said he would tear up NAFTA. He has said that he wants to renegotiate it to get better terms. It's an open question what would happen if Canada and/or Mexico aren't inclined to go along with his terms, as it then turns into a very dangerous game of chicken. The big question might be whether Trump *understands* how important NAFTA is (in this article, Mr Donohue says that he does). Pretending not to understand it could be posturing for negotiation -- like the driver playing chicken who removes his steering wheel and waves it out the window for the other driver to see.

I suspect very few small businesses (fewer than 100 employees) especiare incorporated to avoid taxes. They do so to further their owners' dreams, indulge their passions, to live as independent people (as opposed to being a "wage-slave,", in short, "to be the boss.") and, of course, the hope that they'll more money than they would as employees. For most, "Making more money" by avoiding taxes is, for most, a ridiculous strategy. That's like saving dimes as you make the dollars. Big deal. 

Many businesses (including self-employed & micro-enterprises--1-4 employees) incorporate to LIMIT LIABILITY. If times get really tough, creditors can't come after your personal assets. That was my motivation.

Comment: Diverdave, as a Hawaiian Studies major from UH, allow me to correct your revisionist history of the Hawaiian people.  First, theories abound to the origin of Native Hawaiians - there's no hard evidence to back your claim that entire ethnic groups of people were being enslaved here pre-white plantation era Hawai'i.  

Second, Native Hawaiians - Kanaka Maoli - are the product of a number of waves of Pacific Island settlers.  It's hardly accurate to say that "Tahitians" or "Marquesas" were the first people here, when Native Hawaiians have genealogical ties to every wave of Pacific Island settlers pre-Cook arrival - Native Hawaiians/Kanaka Maoli were the first people here.  

The 1893 Overthrow disfranchised most Native Hawaiians from politics.  There's clear evidence of this throughout the last decade of the 19th century and it culminates in a majority of Native Hawaiians protesting the insurrectionist government in a formal petition to the US (aka Anti-Annexation Petitions).

Comment: I will point out that the Nuclear Safety and Control Act (federal legislation) does grant authority to the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission to regulate and control the handling of radioactive material. So legislation does exist.  
But, I don't see the logic of allowing politicians and ignorant voting masses to govern a process for determining a safe solution to disposal of nuclear waste in Canada.  
Let me put it to you this way:  We can all agree that we should fix congenital heart defects in children.  But we don't ask voters to weigh in on how the procedure should be carried out.  We leave it to medical professionals, regulated by Health Canada.
In the same way, we all agree nuclear waste should be properly and safely disposed of.  But in this case, we feel technical expertise is not to be trusted, and only politicians and the ignorant masses can find the real solution.
Either you trust the experts or you don't.  You can't pick and choose your science.

Comment: Excellent, excellent, article Mr. Wohlforth.

At the time of Molly Hootch many two things were factors that are no longer the case today:
1. Alaska was a dumping ground for inadequate and criminal individuals (cops, teachers, priests, nurses) who had been chased out of the Lower 48. Internet database and simple google searches now identify such people.
2. Life at a boarding school was a distant solitary affair. Now cell phones, skype, email, jet service to hubs, and multiple air taxis keep students much better and more closely connected to their families.
 
Finally, the "promise" of Molly Hootch (which everyone knew would be costly) that students would participate in both village and global life has not come to fruition. The schools came to provide that global connection, but for various reasons the villages/villagers have shirked their side and the benefits of a locally based school have never been fully realized.

Not even after ww1 or ww2 did a country by the name of Ukraine even exist. There was ancient Galicja which was the basis of the Ukraine.But as noted Galicja became a part of everyone else's empire through the centuries from at least 1400 onward. Today Galicja is a part of the Ukraine. The Ukraine should exist but it is the western part only. Eastern Ukraine is primarily Russian.

Comment: "It is within the realm of possibility that the SCC rules that wait times for some comparatively simple surgical procedures, like joint replacement, are unreasonably long and a violation of Charter rights, thereby opening the door to private, for fee clinics."

It's possible the SCC could rule that way. But there's differences between the delivery of timely justice and the delivery of health services. The first is an explicit Charter right that falls directly within the Supreme Court's role. The latter is a service the government decided to provide for political reasons, and with which the SCC has no direct expertise. 

I also think it's a stretch, even were the SCC to rule as you suggest, that it could open the door for private health clinics. That's like imagining the Jordan ruling could've opened the door to privatized prosecutions and trials.

Comment: The PFD is not wealth distribution because it does not come from tax payers, which is why it boosts the economy. The money comes from the Alaska constitution granting the citizens of Alaska the mineral rights to state land. Back when oil was being pumped out like gang busters, someone had a brilliant idea of investing all the oil profit into the stock market as a huge principle, and then pay out the interest made from the principle to the Alaskan people, as opposed to simply cutting them a check for their share of the oil profit.
Long story short, the money IS ours, not the state's, because Alaskans (not Alaska) own the mineral rights that made the principle for the PFD. We are getting the interest from our share of the states minerals, that's all.

Laurie Finlayson
